head.title: Muscular Tissue and the Skeletal Musclular System

body.p: When discussing the skeletal muscular system, it is important to review some terminology to avoid confusion. Remember that a system is typically defined as a group of organs that contribute to a particular function (or functions). The skeletal muscular system doesn’t cleanly fit this definition since it contributes to many of the body’s functions (such as chewing for digestion, diaphragm for breathing, etc.). Thus the skeletal muscle system is a unique system, responsible for movements in the body. In this unit, we will also consider all of the body’s muscle tissues: skeletal, cardiac and smooth. Technically, the organ made of cardiac muscle (the heart) is part of the cardiovascular system. However, many of the molecular, cellular and tissue level features are similar to skeletal muscle, so we will present all types of muscles here. We will start by reviewing the different levels of the muscular system.

When most people think of muscles, they think of skeletal muscles that are visible just under the skin. In athletes, skeletal muscles are especially toned to supply strong and precise forces for movement. The adaptability of skeletal muscles allows changes in mass as a result of how much or how little use they get. When a skeletal muscle increases in size, it does so by adding structural proteins to individual cells, but it does not increase the number of muscle cells present. In addition to generating motion, muscles also restrain motion. Restraining motion is just as important as generating it: muscles hold the bones in position to keep the skeleton upright.

Other types of muscles are less visible than skeletal muscles but are just as important. As already noted, smooth muscles aid in the control of airflow in the respiratory tract, blood flow in blood vessels, and movement of food in the gastrointestinal tract, among many other functions. Cardiac muscle maintains blood flow through the heart and generates the pressure to move blood throughout the rest of the body.

Skeletal muscles produce locomotion (movement to get around) and any movement that can be consciously controlled. Whereas most skeletal muscles are attached to bone, some skeletal muscles are attached to other muscles and skin. Because force generation typically requires conscious control from the nervous system, skeletal muscle is called voluntary muscle. This voluntary control is achieved through neural control, which transmits information from the brain and spinal cord to the muscle. Skeletal muscle can exert a wide range of force depending on the task. Muscles in the arm can lift a very light pen, a very heavy dumbbell, and everything in between.

Cardiac muscle tissue is only found in the heart. Contractions of cardiac muscle pump blood throughout the body and maintain blood pressure. Similar to skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle is striated, but unlike skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle cannot be consciously controlled and is thus called involuntary muscle. Cardiac contractions are controlled by the pacemaker cells
a group of cells in the heart that directly initiate heart muscle contraction by firing spontaneous action potentials
, leading to a fairly steady and consistent heartbeat. To change the rate of contractions, the pacemaker cells can react to stimuli, such as circulating hormones or the autonomic nervous system (nervous functions outside of conscious control). Neurotransmitters and hormones such as those produced in response to fear can modulate the rate at which contractions occur by influencing the pacemaker cells.

Smooth muscle tissue is present in the walls of hollow organs and structures that transport and hold material including digestive organs (stomach) and urinary organs (bladder), as well as respiratory tracts (trachea) and circulatory tracts (arteries). Smooth muscle also plays specialized roles in the body. For example, it is present in the eyes, where it functions to change the size of the iris and alter the shape of the lens. Smooth muscle also causes hair to stand erect in response to cold temperature or fear. Smooth muscle has no striations, as it does not possess the microscopic organizing structures found in skeletal and cardiac muscle; it is therefore called nonstriated muscle. Smooth muscle is not under voluntary control; thus, it is also called involuntary muscle. The triggers for smooth muscle contraction include hormones, neural stimulation, and even stretch.
